parent.description: A folder with different standard content types that Plone supports out of the box
parent.title: Examples

text.data:
Spaces and related

The following should all appear as spaces of various widths:

  • X X X X Y (space; breakable)
  • XÂ XÂ XÂ XÂ Y (no-break space; unbreakable)
  • Xâ€€Xâ€€Xâ€€Xâ€€Y (en quad; breakable)
  • Xâ€Xâ€Xâ€Xâ€Y (em quad; breakable)
  • Xâ€‚Xâ€‚Xâ€‚Xâ€‚Y (en space; breakable)
  • Xâ€ƒXâ€ƒXâ€ƒXâ€ƒY (em space; breakable)
  • Xâ€„Xâ€„Xâ€„Xâ€„Y (three-per-em space; breakable)
  • Xâ€…Xâ€…Xâ€…Xâ€…Y (four-per-em space; breakable)
  • Xâ€†Xâ€†Xâ€†Xâ€†Y (six-per-em space; breakable)
  • Xâ€‡Xâ€‡Xâ€‡Xâ€‡Y (figure space; unbreakable)
  • Xâ€ˆXâ€ˆXâ€ˆXâ€ˆY (punctuation space; same width as a period)
  • Xâ€‰Xâ€‰Xâ€‰Xâ€‰Y (thin space)
  • Xâ€ŠXâ€ŠXâ€ŠXâ€ŠY (hair space)
  • Xâ€‹Xâ€‹Xâ€‹Xâ€‹Y (zero width space; breakable)
  • XXXXY (zero width no-break space; unbreakable)

General punctuation

The convention in English is â€œto use double quotation marks to indicate quotation, and â€˜single quotation marksâ€™ for nested quotations.â€

En franÃ§ais la convention est Â«Â d'utiliser les guillemets franÃ§ais doubles pour les citations, et â€œÂ les guillemets anglais doublesÂ â€ ou bien â€¹Â les guillemets franÃ§ais simplesÂ â€º pour les citations imbriquÃ©es.Â Â»

Auf Deutsch ist die Vereinbarung Â»umgekehrte zweifache AnfÃ¼hrungszeichen fÃ¼r die Zitate zu benutzen, sogar â€ºeinfache AnfÃ¼hrungszeichenâ€¹ fÃ¼r die verschachtelte ZitateÂ«; diese AnfÃ¼hrungszeichen â€dÃ¼rfen auch solche â€šenglischeâ€˜ AnfÃ¼hrungszeichen sein.â€œ

The en-dash is used between numbers such as in: 1685â€“1750 (J.Â S.Â Bach). It is longer than the hyphen (as in â€œen-dashâ€, or, more properly, â€œenâ€dashâ€) but shorter than the em-dash, which is used â€” like this â€” as a sort of parenthesis. Neither should be confused with the horizontal bar which is used to introduce quotation in some cases.
â€•Â Like this?
â€•Â Right.

The ellipsis isâ€¦ well, it just is.

A table of (some) accents

In the following table, characters that are missing from Unicode as of version 3.0, latest draft (i.e. that cannot be represented as aÂ singleÂ character but must use the more general form of combining diacritics) have been replaced byÂ X, so you can tell they are not your browser's fault.

Note that the three characters â€œLATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH DOT ABOVEâ€, â€œLATIN SMALL LETTER O WITH DOT ABOVEâ€ and â€œLATIN SMALL LETTER Y WITH MACRONâ€ were not present in version 2.0 of the Unicode standard. So it is quite understandable if you do not see the corresponding entries.

Combining diacritics

The following paragraph gives a few forms formed by using combining diacritics. The equal sign means that the combined form on the left should be identical in all respects (and in particular, represented identically) to the atomic form on the right. To emphasize even more: you shouldÂ notÂ seeÂ twoÂ signs on the left of the equal sign butÂ one, the same as on the right.
